description: From Middle English hoppen, from Old English hoppian (“to hop, spring, leap, dance”), from Proto-Germanic *huppōną (“to hop”), from Proto-Indo-European *kewb- (“to bend, bow”). Cognate with Dutch hoppen (“to hop”), German hopfen, hoppen (“to hop”), Swedish hoppa (“to hop, leap, jump”), Icelandic hoppa (“to hop, skip”).

entries.meaning: A short jump.
examples: The frog crossed the brook in three or four hops.

entries.meaning: A jump on one leg.
A short journey, especially in the case of air travel, one that takes place on a private plane.
(sports, US) A bounce, especially from the ground, of a thrown or batted ball.
(US, dated) A dance; a gathering for the purpose of dancing.
(networking) The sending of a data packet from one host to another as part of its overall journey.

verbs.description: hop (third-person singular simple present hops, present participle hopping, simple past and past participle hopped)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To jump a short distance.
(intransitive) To jump on one foot.
(intransitive) To be in state of energetic activity.
examples: Sorry, can't chat. Got to hop.
The sudden rush of customers had everyone in the shop hopping.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To suddenly take a mode of transportation that one does not drive oneself, often surreptitiously.
examples: I hopped a plane over here as soon as I heard the news.
He was trying to hop a ride in an empty trailer headed north.
He hopped a train to California.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To jump onto, or over
(intransitive, usually in combination) To move frequently from one place or situation to another similar one.
examples: We had to island-hop on the weekly seaplane to get to his hideaway.

entries.meaning: (informal, intransitive) To go in a quick or sudden manner.
examples: She hopped on the computer and typed away, going back and forth between Mark's fake I.D., the deposit slip and the computer screen.

entries.meaning: (informal) To dance.
(obsolete) To walk lame; to limp.

description: From Middle English hoppe, from Middle Dutch hoppe, from Old Dutch *hoppo, from Proto-Germanic *huppô. Cognate with German Hopfen and French houblon.

entries.meaning: The plant (Humulus lupulus) from whose flowers beer or ale is brewed.
(usually in the plural) The flowers of the hop plant, dried and used to brew beer etc.
(US, slang) Opium, or some other narcotic drug.
The fruit of the dog rose; a hip.

verbs.description: hop (third-person singular simple present hops, present participle hopping, simple past and past participle hopped)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To impregnate with hops, especially to add hops as a flavouring agent during the production of beer
(intransitive) To gather hops.
